head.headtext: Privilege against self-incrimination—Privilege of an accused not to be a witness against himself

para.paratext: The law is clear that a person charged with a criminal offense may claim the constitutional privilege against self-incrimination and remain silent or waive his privilege and become a witness. Georgia courts have zealously protected from comment those accused who claim the privilege against self-incrimination.[1] A defendant's failure to testify “shall create no presumption against him or her,”[2] and the prosecutor may not call the criminal defendant to the stand or otherwise make any comment upon a defendant's failure to testify at trial.[3] Therefore, while the prosecution may generally “argue that evidence showing guilt has not been rebutted or contradicted,” it cannot mention or allude to the defendant's failure to testify on his own behalf.[4] References which may incidentally allude to the defendant's failure to testify may not be grounds for reversal. In Eason v. State,[5] the Georgia Court of Appeals established a two prong test for determining whether a prosecutor's reference to the defendant's failure to testify constitutes reversible error. “Generally, comments by the State regarding the defendant's decision not to testify may constitute reversible error if (1) the prosecutor's manifest intention was to comment on the accused's failure to testify or (2) the remark was of such a character that a jury would naturally and necessarily take it to be a comment on the accused's failure to testify.”[6] In Eason, the prosecutor objected to defense counsel's questioning of a police officer regarding the defendant's reaction to the victim's allegations. The prosecutor argued in front of the jury that the question solicited hearsay, which was not against interest, and that if counsel makes a proffer, “His client can take the stand and it will come out.” Although the court refused to conclude that the statements by the prosecutor were proper, it held that reversal was not required because neither prong of the foregoing test was satisfied.[7]

Moreover, the privilege against self-incrimination must be safeguarded by the trial court to the greatest extent possible. The court must give clear and complete jury instructions which encompass minimizing the danger that a jury will give evidentiary weight to the fact that a defendant elected not to testify. The trial court must therefore instruct the jury, when asked, not to consider the failure of the defendant to testify “in any way.”[8]

There is no blanket privilege against self-incrimination in civil proceedings, however, including civil forfeiture actions, and the trier of fact may properly draw negative inferences from the defendant's invocation of his right.[9] Such inferences may constitute admissions unfavorable to the party. Moreover, in a case of first impression, the Court of Appeals held that the trial court had abused its discretion where the trial court granted a motion to stay civil proceedings until the conclusion of a related criminal trial, where the defendant argued having to defend the civil matter would force him to assert his Fifth Amendment rights, which would allow the jury to draw an adverse inference, because the civil trial was scheduled for trial before his criminal prosecution.[10] The court may sustain the privilege against self-incrimination in civil proceedings where it is evident from the implication of the question that a responsive answer might be dangerous because injurious disclosure may result.[11]

O.C.G.A. § 24-5-506(b) states that, if a defendant in a criminal case wishes to testify and announces in open court his or her intention to do so, the defendant may so testify in his or her own behalf. If a defendant testifies, he or she shall be sworn and may be examined and cross-examined as any other witness. Naturally, a defendant who voluntarily takes the stand in his own behalf and testifies as to his guilt or innocence as to a particular offense waives his privilege against self-incrimination.[12] This waiver is not partial.[13] In Braswell v. State, the Georgia Court of Appeals quoted its previous opinion in Hubbard by saying, “Having once cast aside the cloak of immunity, he may not resume it at will, whenever cross-examination may be inconvenient or embarrassing. His voluntary offer of testimony upon any fact is a waiver as to all other relevant facts because of the necessary connection between all.”[14] Thus, once he elects to testify, the defendant becomes a witness like any other witness, must answer all proper and relevant questions on cross examination, and cannot claim the privilege not to incriminate himself.[15] Moreover, if the defendant refuses to testify on cross-examination after testifying on direct, the appropriate sanction by the court is to strike the testimony in its entirety.[16] Once a defendant has elected to testify, it is not ineffective assistance of counsel to question the defendant, even though counsel had urged her not to testify.[17] The jury may properly draw negative inferences from a defendant's assertion of the privilege if he testifies on direct examination, but refuses to answer relevant questions on cross-examination.[18] However, a defendant may testify to limited issues at a hearing on the voluntariness of a confession (a “Jackson Denno”[19] hearing) or on a motion to suppress and his cross-examination would be limited to these issues.[20] In such proceedings, the defendant may testify without waiving his right to invoke the privilege against self-incrimination at a trial later.[21] This is the rule on both the state and federal level because Jackson Denno and suppression hearings are distinguished from other types of pre-trial proceedings in that they are designed to protect the criminal defendant's constitutional rights.[22] As stated by the United States Supreme Court with respect to testimony provided at a hearing on a motion to suppress, “In these circumstances, we find it intolerable that one constitutional right should have to be surrendered in order to assert another.”[23] Georgia courts have not extended the rule to other types of pre-trial proceedings so a criminal defendant's testimony at a bond or probation revocation hearing is admissible against him at trial.[24]

The privilege against self-incrimination not only protects an accused against compelled testimony at trial, but also gives an accused the right to remain silent from the moment of his arrest[25] and protects him from having his pre-arrest silence used against him.[26] The Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution guarantees this aspect of the privilege and federal case-law requires that police give an accused the well-known Miranda[27] warning prior to conducting a “custodial interrogation” before any statement he makes can be used against him. Out of court statements secured in violation of the privilege are not admissible in evidence against him.[28] The state has the burden of showing that its agents gave accused a Miranda warning or that the accused waived his rights thereunder.[29] The Miranda warning does not need to be in writing[30] and is not required in every case. For example, a Miranda warning was not required in a noncustodial interrogation by agents of the Internal Revenue Service even though criminal charges might be involved.[31] Statements made to a welfare worker do not require a Miranda warning.[32] In Riley v. State,[33] the Georgia Supreme Court held that the question of whether a juvenile should receive a Miranda warning and waiver would be determined from the “totality of the circumstances.”[34] Moreover, statements of apology made by a juvenile during his intake process were not against his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination as the as the statements were not made during a custodial interrogation.[35]

The United States Supreme Court held in Berkemer v. McCarty[36] that a Miranda warning applies to a custodial interrogation of a suspect accused of a misdemeanor traffic offense, but roadside questioning of a motorist does not constitute custodial interrogation. A Miranda warning is not necessary if a reasonable person would believe that his detention is temporary.[37] In Oregon v. Elstad,[38] the court held that a confession made after a proper Miranda warning and a valid waiver was admissible despite the police obtaining an earlier voluntary, but unwarned, admission from the suspect. However, the court considered the issue more completely in the 2004 case of Missouri v. Seibert[39] where the law enforcement officer made the conscious decision not to give a Miranda warning initially and obtained an incriminating statement before delivering the warning. The court used a multi-factor test to determine whether the Miranda warnings, “delivered midstream,” would accomplish the object of protecting the suspect's rights. The factors include completeness and detail of the questions in the first round before the Miranda warnings were given, whether and how the statements overlapped, the time and setting of the interrogations, whether the same police personnel questioned the suspect, and the degree to which the second round of questions were treated as continuous with the first.[40] The Court concluded that the Miranda warnings given mid-interrogation, after the defendant had already provided an unwarned confession, were ineffective and the defendant's post-warning confession was inadmissible at trial.[41]

Likewise, the Georgia Court of Appeals concluded that statements made by a defendant while in custody, after he had asserted his privilege were improperly attained, yet the court found the error harmless based on the overwhelming evidence against the defendant.[42]

This application of the privilege, like the others, can be waived. Under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-824, any waiver of the privilege must be voluntary “without being induced by another by the slightest hope of benefit or remotest fear of injury.”

A statement given by a defendant because another person induced the hope of lighter punishment constitutes “hope of benefit” and renders the statement inadmissible.[43] For example, in Canty v. State,[44] the Georgia Supreme Court held that a confession was made involuntarily when the defendant was told that confessing to the crime could result in a “shorter term.” Similarly, “a promise that the defendant will not face a certain charge creates an impermissible hope of benefit that renders an incriminating statement inadmissible.”[45] However, in Owens v. State,[46] the defendant's contention that he viewed the investigating detective as a “mother figure” did not require exclusion of his confession.

The courts have held that there was no “hope of benefit” when police offered to help the defendant find a psychologist and suggested that it behooved defendant to tell the truth;[47] a police officer promised that he would inform the district attorney's office of the defendant's cooperation;[48] or where a victim's parent represented that he would not involve the police.[49] Additionally, a promise concerning a collateral benefit for the accused will not render his subsequent confession excludable.[50]

The Georgia Court of Appeals has held that statements referring to an accused “going home” after an interview are collateral promises that in no way relate to the sentence or charges facing the suspect.[51] A police officer may dispel any hope of benefit the accused may have by stating that he has no influence over the accused's possible punishment.[52]

It is also established that the Fifth Amendment does not prevent grand juries from compelling the attendance of witnesses; however, a defendant may assert his rights against self-incrimination when testifying.[53]

U.S. v. Hasting, 461 U.S. 499, 103 S. Ct. 1974, 76 L. Ed. 2d 96 (1983), held that the comment on the failure of the defendant to testify, if it was a comment at all, was harmless error under Griffin v. California, 380 U.S. 609, 85 S. Ct. 1229, 14 L. Ed. 2d 106 (1965), and Chapman v. California, 386 U.S. 18, 87 S. Ct. 824, 17 L. Ed. 2d 705, 24 A.L.R.3d 1065 (1967).

Linder v. State, supra, and related cases were disapproved in Clay v. State, 236 Ga. 398, 224 S.E.2d 14 (1976), which held that it was error to fail to charge, after a written request, that the failure of the defendant to testify should not create a presumption against him.
It is also not error to give such a charge in the absence of a request. See Woodard v. State, 234 Ga. 901, 218 S.E.2d 629 (1975); Stapleton v. State, 235 Ga. 513, 220 S.E.2d 269 (1975).

If the defendant elects to take the stand and testify, then the prosecutor may comment on his failure to explain or deny the testimony of particular witnesses. Gosha v. State, 239 Ga. 37, 235 S.E.2d 527 (1977).

The Woodard and Stapleton cases, supra, were followed in Drake v. State, 239 Ga. 232, 236 S.E.2d 748 (1977). But in Bryant v. State, 146 Ga. App. 43, 245 S.E.2d 333 (1978), the defendant did not testify. The district attorney said that there was no witness and no evidence that it did not happen. This was held not to be a comment on his failure to testify.

See also Haas v. State, 146 Ga. App. 729, 247 S.E.2d 507 (1978); Rivers v. State, 147 Ga. App. 19, 248 S.E.2d 31 (1978) (abrogated on other grounds by, Moore v. State, 254 Ga. 674, 333 S.E.2d 605 (1985)).

In Lakeside v. Oregon, 435 U.S. 333, 340, 98 S. Ct. 1091, 55 L. Ed. 2d 319 (1978), the trial judge charged the jury, over defense counsel objection, that no inference or presumption against the defendant would arise from his failure to testify. The court held that the charge did not violate the defendant's privilege against self-incrimination and did not deny his right to the assistance of counsel but stated: “It may be wise for a trial judge not to give such a cautionary instruction over a defendant's objection.” It has since been held that it would be prejudicial error to fail to charge the jury that they are not to draw an adverse inference from the defendant's failure to testify when the charge is requested by the defendant. See also Lancaster v. State, 250 Ga. 871, 301 S.E.2d 882 (1983), which considered Riley and held that confession was admissible.

In Bussey v. State, 144 Ga. App. 875, 243 S.E.2d 99 (1978), the court held that former O.C.G.A. § 15-11-19 applies to a juvenile who was later tried as an adult and that failure to comply would render the confession inadmissible.

The burden on the government to prove waiver in cases involving children is generally heavier than for adults. Hance v. State, 245 Ga. 856, 268 S.E.2d 339 (1980). To determine whether Miranda rights were validly waived, the court must consider the age of the accused, education, manner of interrogation, and other factors. Chapman v.
